name: UnEpic
description: Daniel was just an average guy. He was a great videogame player, a big fan of sci-fi movies, and a novice RPG player. In the midst of an RPG, he was teleported to a castle. At first, Daniel believed that he was having a massive hallucination.
minimum_requirements: OS:Windows XP Processor:Dual Core Memory:4 GB GB RAM Graphics:256mb, Compatible with OpenGL DirectX®:7.0 Hard Drive:256mb disk space Sound:Direct Sound installedNOTE: Some ATI graphics cards require troubleshooting because their drivers are not 100% compatible with OpenGL. If you have concerns, try <a href="https://steamcommunity.com/linkfilter/?url=http://www.unepicgame.com/files/unepic.exe" target="_blank" rel="noopener"  >running the demo first.
recommended_requirements: Recomended: OS:Windows XP or later Processor:Quad Core Memory:8GB Graphics:Nvidia Geforce 512GB or more DirectX®:7.0 or later Hard Drive:256mb disk space Sound:Direct Sound installedNOTE: Some ATI graphics cards require troubleshooting because their drivers are not 100% compatible with OpenGL. If you have concerns, try <a href="https://steamcommunity.com/linkfilter/?url=http://www.unepicgame.com/files/unepic.exe" target="_blank" rel="noopener"  >running the demo first.

reviews.review_text: Unepic is an old-school indie RPG that’s rough around the edges but still has a lot to offer. You play as Daniel, a typical nerd who suddenly finds himself either hallucinating or somehow transported inside the tabletop game he’s been playing—he’s not sure which.  Soon after, you are exploring a castle full of deadly enemies and traps, searching for the exit. The dungeon is divided into segments typical of a Metroidvania, requiring you to power up, level up, defeat an area’s boss to obtain a key so you may progress to the next area, and so on. The boss battles themselves are well-crafted and interesting, except for one that effectively forces you to drop your items on the ground, which was a terrible idea.   You’ll meet a reluctant companion very early on who will remain with you throughout the game and serves as the other half of most of the dialog and story. The dialog tends to be on the humorous side and tries, maybe a little too hard, at incorporating some nerd humor and pop culture references into everything you do.  There are many secrets to be found within the walls of the castle; shopkeepers and quest givers to meet; pets to recruit, who will follow you around and offer unique abilities; and in-game challenges to complete, which are actually quite challenging. A robust magic system, based on reagents and eight schools of magic, is in place along with alchemy and your typical melee and ranged skills and weapons. Leveling up will let you distribute stat points and skill points across these as you see fit, with harder difficulties rewarding you with more points to distribute as well as the ability to save your game manually.  Unepic does have its flaws: Other than the humor not being for everyone, even people who typically don’t get hung up on graphics may find the game to be ugly and, while the lighting can be nicely done, the minigame of wading through the darkness to light all the torches can become tiring, as can climbing ladders on every screen. In spite of this, a solid RPG lies at the core and it’s obvious the developer put a lot of work, and love, into making the game.

You know what the problem is with fantasy parodies? The task seems to be too easy. How hard can it be? A bunch of old guys with long white beards, couple of mentally disabled protagonists, dark overlord behaving like an angsty teenager — there you have it, add a few butt jokes and we’re good. And when you look closer it turns out there’s not a lot of more than a mix-up of ♥♥♥♥ jokes, fart jokes and lots of people “hilariously” falling for whatever reasons. When the genre itself is balancing acrobat on the string of heroic attitude strained upon an abyss of mindless self-repetitive nonsense, it's so easy to make a parody that is just bad example of the genre itself. I think you guessed what I think of UnEpic’s script. It’s a story of pimply geek Daniel, teleported into the dungeons of castle of the Dark Overlord right in the middle of D&D session. And if that doesn’t give you enough notion, this magical transportation happened when he walked to have a leak, because he drank too much beer. Upon arrival our hero makes contact with some dark spirit, it ends up with spirit being trapped in protagonist’s body (or rather mind?) and capable of nothing more than talking. And that he does a lot! Mostly sarcastically, and rarely speaking the truth. Believing that he’s having a very realistic hallucination our ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ protagonist starts his quest, which is of course nothing less than slaying the biggest villain here. And so it starts, the mix-up of ♥♥♥♥ jokes, and fart jokes and quests which quite bluntly task you with ♥♥♥♥ing an orc; and ex-virgin geek is happy to do it. So, if UnEpic couldn’t give you anything besides this rather unartful humour it shouldn’t be even worth writing about. But thankfully from a merit of a game it’s no joke. The game won’t win a prize for the most sophisticated world, but it sure is vast. There’s no shortage of easily missable side-quests, different enemies and varying pieces of valuable equipment. But while actually there’s not a lot of need for trying out some magic or ranged weapons, you sure can experiment a lot. But hey, no every game can be Transistor and give you a meaningful stimulus for trying out everything. Sometimes the joy of toying with varying mechanics is enough of a reward for itself. What sure is absolutely mandatory for easy game progression is crafting and collecting all sort of magical scrolls, wands and ingredients for making potions. Power-ups help quite a lot, especially on those hard-hitting bosses, who usually aren’t very tricky, but require a bit of a precise movement which isn’t something that can be easily achieved considering monstrous control scheme (and I don’t even want to know into a what more horrible mess it become when game was ported on Wii U). All the downsides of the game are tolerable in the end, when it comes to really superb level design, with a slow but interesting progression path. The castle slowly turns from Terra Incognita into your playground, where you casually go for a walk for another pack of so valuable satyr intestines. Then there’s this key and that key, and new area, and new enemies which require careful planning before you rush off into the battle. Monsters are quite powerful, have the same reach as a player and often enough they output more damage, while being invincible to some types of attack. UnEpic looks, feels and plays a lot like very old metroidvania, and even contains homage to The Maze of Galious, 1987 game by Konami for MSX and Famicom; developer calls it the main source of inspiration for a game. This retro-feel sure is nice, it has a substance of real love to those games, and while sometimes it can be a bit rough to get in to, it sure knows what to do once the player got its pace.

The absolutely best part of UnEpic is the fact that you get tons of (mostly crude) humour, but surprisingly the game itself is also quite playable and offers a nice variety of spells, weapons and fighting styles. I wouldn't recommend this one for the ones easily offended and lacking any sense of humour whatsoever. I would — for those who value vulgar nerdy jokes and might gladly trade ~20 hrs of life for a pack of lulz. I did and had fun with it!  and   Wow the end is really cool    if you know what I mean

I played this game before it came on this platform and reached the end. It's a thoroughly enjoyable title with  crisp graphics, smooth animation, suitable music and sound effects and a general good feeling of solid gameplay . I enjoyed most of the humor in it, as well. Some (too) obvious movie/etc references here and there.. But overall nice touches that blend in with the story. Would you believe that this very platform rejected it at first because.. wait for it.. it didn't fit their 'specifications' for the games they wanted here? Yep, take a look at some random Greenpo..erm..light titles nowdays and you will be astonished at the above decision. It's a one-man-game and for that it gets extra points for being so good at what it does. The price may seem a bit steep-ish but  it's totally worth it.

This game is beautifully made. I love every minute of the dialog! So many movie references, I love it! Even if you die in the game its actually quite rewarding hilarious. I recommended this game to many of my friends who love RPG /DnD games.

If you want an epic experience, ignore the title and buy this game. Right now. TLDR: Refined retro-style graphics Good humor, option to switch between adult humor and.. safer humor Platformer, simple combat system with flexibility Lots of items, weapons, and spells Rogue-like atmosphere, but maybe not mechanics Simple RPG skill tree that doesn't take hours to master  UnEpic, at first glance, is a platformer with CGs and very simplistic, almost retro-style graphics and UI. The graphics may look subpar compared to modern gaming, but remember that the game is based off of Metroidvania, 2D hack and slash with more emphasis on action than aesthetics. When you start up the game, you get a cutscene of a couple of guys playing Dungeons and Dragons, with nothing but an overhead lantern and a ton of beer. Next thing you know, you're in a medieval castle filled with traps, monsters, and loot. The rest is up to you. UnEpic is a great game. Gameplay wise, you have simple yet complex with a basic 'space to attack' and arrow key movement. Throw in about 10 different weapon types, pets that assist in combat and out, potions that have various effects, and an expansive (it's not that bad) character skill page. You now have a game that combines the best of rogue-like, RPG, hack and slash, and platformer. As for the protagonist, you play as Strider, also known as Aragorn II, son of Arathorn and his companion Zera, the wight of- Nevermind, your name is Daniel. You're a gamer, a sci-fi fanatic, and you have a sharp tongue for sarcasm and inappropriate jokes, especially at the expense of the equally as sarcastic spirit that tried and failed to possess you. Expect every encounter with friend, or foe, to make you smile at least once before blood is spilt. The castle itself is a labyrinth of rooms that, thankfully, do not change constantly. Explore, fill in your map and make notes on what's here, what's there, where your quest door is- Light up rooms full of monsters and treasure, and a ton of breakable barrels. For the completionists, grab every chest and light every torch. For the hunters, destroy every monster in your path with the arsenal of weapons and magics stuffed in the side pocket of your jeans. Expect alarming encounters with big bosses like dragons or worms, and swarms of smaller minions like.. dragons. And worms. Collect materials, brew potions, find gold, buy loot. You want candles? You want swords? You want books? Zoran, Zorak, Ubuntu, and Fedora have got you covered. Do menial tasks for handicapped goblins! Ever wanted to kill the puppy-version of Sindel? How about look for a silver ring in a dark room? How about go rescue an ice elemental from a boiling cauldron? Buy this game! It has singleplayer and multiplayer, the latter of which I have not tried but it looks awesome. Set aside a lot of time, however. Postpone that Dungeons and Dragons game with your buddies until next week. But whatever you do, don't go to the bathroom with the lights off.
One hell of an amazing game. The replayability of this game is awesome, i actually need some people to play multiplayer with add me? :)
Best Platformer-Rpg game i ever played! Awesome single player campaign for ~12 hours and excellent D&D-like multiplayer. Just an epic game, nothing more to say about it.
A really fun, challenging game to play. Some of the movement is sloppy, but aside from that its a good game with a great level/loot system.
I would highly recommend this if you are looking for a fun dungeon RPG coop game. Multiplayer isn't finished, but the multiplayer stuff that is released is very addictive. Awesome deal at $8

Really amazing game. Impressive plot. The idea of a real player entering in a misterious castle and trespass through enemies and challenges it's really delightful.  Just becareful if you are collecting quest itens. Do not forget them when you change room, because the goblins can appear and steal it.
Smoky dude possesed me... Says there is an emergency gas exit in my body.  11/10 would fart smoky dude

You can really feel the devs care about this game.    And a great game it is. It's both challenging and fun, with a good sense of humor most of the time. It can get frustrating too, especially the rare platforming parts, but overall it's an enjoyable game.  The story is interesting, the voice acting is pretty good, the overall gameplay is pretty well thought out. The combat is simple, but it works well within it's set constraints.  The game gets more challenging near the end (hint: hope you increased your ranged skills) but nothing that can't be overcome.

What happen when you mix a game like La-Mulana with RPG-styled level ups? You get UnEpic. If you can handle the high difficulty curve and slightly awkward out-of-the-box controls, you'll find a heck of a game, a sprawling exploration-based platformer that will put your dungeon-crawling skills to the test.  Don't forget to bring a light!

I like the idea and the way how you play though at some point I got kinda stuck and my motivation wasn't high enough to spent some more time to get further. I would really like to see the whole story but I don't want to play through everything I think this can be a lot of fun, just not for me ^^

What a gem this game turned out to be. A very smooth combat system, very easy controls, and focus on gameplay rather than micro-managing things leaves you open to explore. Add in the humor, and you have an excellent time.
UnEpic is one the best RPG platforming game of all history.

So after 100+ hours of gameplay I thought a review would be nice. I would call myself a casual RPG player and yet I've only played the single-player mode.  I played three characters and I enjoyed the game from the beginning to the end!    Pro:
An addictive platformer with great mechanics, tight controls, and lots of juvenile humor.
I really love this game, a perfect metroidvania style game! Recommended!

UnEpic is a brilliant (not so) little indie game. We accompany a real-life 'nerd' that gets sucked into a castle full of traps and hostile creatures, trying to find his way out of the 'hallucination', he gets possessed, by one of the guardians of the castle, which doesn't really go too well for both of them. And this where the fun begins.  The whole game is kept in a comedic setting, which is upheld mainly by the witty dialogues (monologues?) between the 'hero' and the spirit. There are lots of references and parodies of different fantasy and science-fiction films throughout the gameplay. The story, even though fairly simple, is actually quite interesting and I caught myself wondering 'how will this end?' many time when playing. However, on several occassions, the humour was just too low and a bit cringeworthy (most notably, 'a dream come true' quest, argh!). Apart from that, seeing the two main characters, argue or make fools of one another was really enjoyable.  As for the game itself, I was surprised by the sheer amount of possibilities to build your character. One is given plenty of tools to do the job right and can just pick the ones that suit him the most. I rarely replay games, but I'm sure I could play UnEpic again, levelling my character in a totally different way and would still succeed. The game doesn't hold one by his hand too much, so sometimes a little thinking is required, when trying to complete some quests. That said, there are scrolls sold by one merchant in the game that will point you out directly to the places you need to go, if someone would get stuck and wouldn't like to search for the answers in the Internet.   Mechanically, the game was ok. The character response to pressing buttons felt a bit weird at first, but I got used to it fairly quick and it didn't bother me at all for the rest of the time. I think, the feeling of unresponsiveness was mainly caused by the fact that the attack animations are somewhat long and that makes attacking and dodging harder. That said, this is not a trick jump, button mashing game, so it's not THAT important. In most cases, the strategy of beating a room/boss is much more important than the execution of it.  As I've already mentioned bosses, UnEpic features some really enjoyable boss fights. Every boss requires a different tactics, which you have to work out in few tries usually. And that is usually enough to beat every boss, except one, which I didn't really like, who is really annoying and requires you to, actually, throw away most of your stuff from the inventory or face death. Apart from that one fight, the others are really great and fulfilling.  The graphics and music (was there even music?) is a totally different story and this is where the 'Indie' shows. I really can't tell if there was music in the game, if there was, I turned it off almost instantly and used my own playlists for the background soundtrack. On the other hand, the voicing is on a decent level, the characters sounded as one could think judging by how they were depicted. The graphics is, well, not so good, so this might be a chokepoint for some players, who look for some high-budget, 3d, flashy backgrounds and animations. Some enemies/bosses look a bit kitschy, but to be honest, the gameplay and the way story goes makes up for that totally.  I've encountered few bugs and crashes, nothing too serious though. Two most annoying were stucking movement and automatic resolution changes. The first one appeared several times to me and even got me killed once or twice, the second one was a bit weird and might have been caused by me pressing some hidden key combination (no idea, couldn't find anything) and was resolved by exiting and entering the saved game. Not sure if others also got those, or is it me doing something wrong. Anyway, nothing too groundbreaking and spoiling the fun too much.  All in all, I really do recommend UnEpic, even at the full price. It is a really fine mix of witty dialogues, crude and/or intelligent humour, movie references, difficulty level and boss fights. What's more, it gives you about 15h+ of gameplay (medium difficulty, all quests), which is a fair amount of time, not too much and definitely not too little. So, if you're on the fence about buying UnEpic, take my word and get it, it's worth it.  P.S. Wow, the ending is really cool!
'Wow, the end is really cool!'    Zera made me say it.    It's a tough RPG platformer with an even tougher multiplayer mode.
Wow, the end was really cool.

imho best of his kind, very funny story, i enjoyed it a lot. Also very addicting makes you want to unlock and explore everything in the game without getting bored doing it. i recommend it to all metroidvania fans!!!
Just play it. It's damn good.
FREAKING AWESOME! YES I RECOMMEND THIS. WHY AM I YELLING>>>??? reasons I guess

Hi Everyone,  I would try to bore you not with the usual review about this game. I would rather like to express what i think of the publisher instead.  In a world without magic and with too cold-hearted industry driven sod. Fran deserve the honour to be regarded as a human, in the most genuine way your hearth will find. He've done a really funny game, entertaining in more than a way, he made it so that you'll end up finding the game mirroring something in your real gamer-life, for me it was the master at the beginning of the game that looks exactly like a friend of mine, but most importantly, as a publisher he cares for his customers and nowadays that's truely UnEpic.  I would treat him to a beer or two if i could, but since i can't, i'm going to buy a copy of his other game asap, and support him the way an HAPPY customer should...   Hands up for Fran!!
Wow! the ending is really cool!
Gameplay - Solid Funny callouts and geek culture references everywhere. Only a little ways in but I can tell its gonna vaccume up my time.  Verdict- Worth every penny.

This game is pretty good I enjoyed it for the most part. When you start out everything is great and so much fun but the further you get the more some of the mechanics just rub you the wrong way. The combat is responsive for the most part and the castle itself was fun to explore, the best part in my opinion. The characters will not be everyone’s cup of tea but overall fun to listen to and see how they develop. Also the story itself was pretty solid.  I would recommend getting this game but don’t feel the need to complete it, especially on the higher difficulties. The payoff is not worth the effort and the keyword for a lot of the game is frustration.  Have fun ^_^
The title lies, the game is epic.
This sums up my experience playing Unepic: 'Wow, the end is really cool!' Zera: Wrong place! Sodomize him! **** 'NO, NO, This is Unepic , unepic at all! NOOOOOO!'
played game without internet got to end 99% finished pc dies switch to laptop install game 90%  ♥♥♥♥ you
I'll take my Castlevania any way possible and Unepic proves that the 2d action platformer genre is well polished in this age of next-gen gimmicky games. Thankyou devs, thanks for being so... AWESOME!
THIS game is so unepic 11/10
This is a pretty laid back adventure. I like it a lot! :)

Fun sidescrolling metroidvania style game with some good references and cultural humor. zoidberg runs by in a part of the game. that cracked me up as it was totally unexpected. you'll die a lot getting the hang of it until you begin using the bow or wands more at points. but the exploration is nice and the things you find like the yoda-like guy are pretty neat. character customization is very flexible you can pop the points you earn leveling up into various skills, which will determine what you can equip and use and how well as weapons had skill level requirements. some of the skills I remember being making potions, spellbooks, wands, gun-types like a laser pistol an achievement point vender sells (I think the pistol fit into the wands skill), swords, axes, the types of armor etc. it's on the monster daily very cheap so worth a grab. it also has online play, but I never tried that though I think some workshop maps are designed for it.
Such a great RPG... It combines old school RPG with some new twists and great laughs.
Pricey but not bad. Not really great either though. Get it on sale.

Do you like DnD? How about just the idea of DnD but not actually playing it? Castlevania? Metroid? Well, apparently this game really appeals to anyone that likes any of that kind of stuff. For a 2D side scroller, I love it. Good gameplay, and nice comedy.  Should definitely try it. 8 / 12

This is what they are talking about when they say you can have a very fun game without needing perty graphix toodoo so. One of those games that makes you use your brain just enough but not too much so blood starts dripping from your nose. It has humor, horror(very little)...well... a bit of everything.    I figured out the reason why everyone likes dungeon adventure games like this... It's because we all like big chests and the booty that goes with...  It also has the element of----> I wanna use this cool ♥♥♥♥ weapon but I have my stats in this cool ♥♥♥♥ weapon.  9.3/10 Bacon!
Awesome game to eat cheese sausages to. 10/10 got crush by chest boulder.
i am loving this game way too much 10/10 only wish the levelling up would be faster
Very interesting and funny game!

The game is unpolished and incomplete. The tutorial alone is broken and getting the hang of the game is really painful. Bug reports are being ignored, because the developer focussed on his new project.  Aside from that, I find the lacking character customization a huge letdown. I'd love to play a female character, but sadly I cannot.  Further, the game 'allows' you to ruin your own experience by demanding a certain character build. If you - for instance - only skill in melee skills, then you'll be stuck further down the line.  In summary: The game is unfinished, riddled with bugs and won't ever be fixed. Stay away unless you don't mind bugs.

'Unepic' is appropriate to this game because it is BORING. The writing drags, the humor falls flat, the combat is repetitive and even the exploration is lackluster. It doesn't help that you're constantly fumbling around in dark and bland hallways. At least it's cheap.

I thought I'd enjoy this but found the mechanics and grinding aspect off-putting. The game has many hours of game play which is a plus but a lot of those are spent trying to figure out where you're going or back tracking to level up to do the next part. This game seems to punish those who want to 'figure it out as they go' in terms of stats, you'll find yourself quite hamstrung if you didn't pick a focus and tried to go all around with your points. There also isn't a good variety when it comes to the best weapons and unless you're psychic knowing what you'll find first and last so you can specialize in time is daunting. To add fat to the fire, if you decide you'd like to cheat (for sake of getting through the story and not having to stress over points) your character just dies. The developer is very against it. For me that's a deal breaker, it might not be for you.

I got this game because it looked like it might be fun and silly. Turns out the humor is lazy and kind of offensive.   I enjoyed myself for the first few minutes, until I got to the 'goblins in heat' sidequest. Your character's a nerd, so of *course* he's desperate enough to screw anything.   I'm not inferring anything. That's what he flat-out says.  I was hoping that kind of 'humor' wasn't characteristic. I was disappointed.  Play something better.

UnEpic is a jewel, single or multiplayer, great story, good humour, funny character, dungeons and more dungeons filled with all sort of monsters . The RPG system is also fine and rewarding, loot everywhere, recipes, magic, npc's, dragons!, etc... you can choose all kind of weapons and then the ones that suits u better, depending on which enemy youre dealing with. Gather your inseparable ZIPPO lighter and make haste! the adventure will be long and creepy... and you will die, probably, here and there...Equip youre ZIPPO again..  Has Steam workshop now, which brings this game to another level.  To all fans of metroidvania style, this is a must buy.  9 out of 10

First of all, until they fixed the gamepad issue, I can not recommend this game. I know not everyone is having the same issues but I would expect Xbox1 controller with Win10 to be work out of the box. To be fair, the game can still be played with keyboard but who would like to play platform games with only keyboard.  I managed to wade through a few minutes and the game looks promising.
Horribly stilted and basic combat. Calling yourself an RPG does not excuse bad gameplay. Story/humor can be pretty amusing, but I still wouldn't recommend the package.
This game is!  Is...  Is...?  Boring as hell.  That's all that can be said, controls are dook, visuals are unappealing and the 'story' is autistic.  Save you money, buy literally anything else.
No working on Mac, really sad ... you should change to 'only available on windows' stop lying to players in order to make money.

The game isn't half bad, but the main character is a mixture of all the worst stereotypes of gamers: Abrasive, elitist, sexist, and pretty much an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Also one of your quests it to have sex with trolls. Literal trolls. Because you're a nerd and thats the only way you can get laid. Seriously.

[Update] I have contacted the developer and received Feedback to the missing multiplayer: - The Multiplayer for Linux will be available when the Linux-Version is released on Linux. - The developer said he would fix this misunderstanding on the website. - Thus, the negative criticism to the missing multiplayer is not relevant anymore. - My negative experience ingame is unchanged  Old Review including 'missing multiplayer': ------------------------------------------------------------------------ I haven't played such a bad game for years.  I bought this game from their website and wanted to play it multiplayer with a friend.  These reasons stopped us: - Mutliplayer does not work in the linux version. This was not mentioned on their website, but will be introduced with the Linux Version on Steam. - The game is not 'challenging', but frustrating -- There are many 'death pits' which a player cannot identify beforehand. -- Monsters kill you in 2 hits, but require 20 hits to die -- Most monsters outrange you by far, leaving the bow as only reasonable weapon -- Casting spells takes VERY long, making it ridiculous to cast spells. -- Boss fights do not require skill, but endurance. You repeat a pattern for ~5-10 minutes.  This is a prime example of very bad game design for me now and I am very frustrated to have bought this. The trailer was AWESOME. The game... sad.
You can't pick up the first gold you see because it kills you. Bad dungeon crawler.
This game is ♥♥♥♥ and heres why.

i have just started playing this game and its very epic dispite its misleading title, first i love the art style and the language used is halarious i liked the part (spoilers btw) where he pretends to be hier to a kingdom he made up even though the world around isnt a drug enduced halucination, i also love the interaction between the protaganist and the try to be antagonist who happens to be stuck in his body (jokes aside) i think the gameplay is very reminicent of castle vania and i like how solid snake and simon belmont are both mentioned. overall a grate game a thoughrly enjoyable

This game is beautiful. This is how most casual (emphasis on 'most') would react and act if they were sucked into a Dungeons & Dragons Universe. Each skill is used for something (that's right guys, no more useless skills that you regret leveling later.) Also each weapon is useful for something. Dagger does bonus damage from stabbing in the back, polearms have longer reach, sword swings slightly faster, maces/axes can break hard objects, bows can be used to either pick off enemies at a distance or you can shoot one, get its attention and draw it over to you and dispatch it quietly as to not alert the other enemies. spells actually require materials to use (and you have to learn/earn the ability use each element of magic) The references to other things (such as LoTR, Golden Child, Star Wars) are somewhat subtly put in (whereas some of them are shoved in your face and you are like 'Yeah i get it. you are trying to make a reference'). Rather than just being a generic hack and slash, loot collection game this actually has a story. and the side missions are actually worth doing! they give you things that aren't required for the main story but make it easier along the way. For only about $12 this game is well worth the price.
Great game with exciting story and great multiplayer. I would definitely recommend this game for everyone who loves RPGs.

Awesome game! One of the first games that I have played in a while that I had trouble pulling away from. Very rewarding and... epic in nature. Witty and comical in presentation with various pop culture references thrown in. I loved it.
Wow. That ending was really good.
Good game, keeps me interested like Zelda did back in the day.

Supringly unexpected good fun.... I am loving th emultiplayer AND the story with all its references to the genre...  VERY well done.  I am slightly miffed with the make your own dungeon tools but this is such a small minus to the overall quality that I am embaressed to mention... :)

This is one of the best games I've played in a long time. It requires you to actually think instead of just going through the motions. Full exploration is rewarded instead of things like Legend of Zelda: Skyward Sword where you are forced to do exactly what needs to be done in the exact order that it needs to be done.  You can wander around into a place that is entirely too powerful for you and die. It's all very intuitive. There hasn't been a side-scroller this good since Castlevania: Symphony of the Night.

'Wow. The end is really cool!'  Once you beat the game (or youtube the endings) you'll get the joke. Unepic is a fantastic Metovania side scroller romp. Almost 50 hours in and loved most of them. Good humor, music and writing. The graphics... they work.

The game is fun and entertaining from the start as you farm money, quest for legendary items and search for hidden corners in a map! However the later part of the game is just very one sided. For a start, bosses. Literally the only bosses that I could kill using melee was the first worm and the eyeball. The rest was just a magic spam. Secondly, weapon balance. Seriously the bow damage and magic damage difference is just far far too much to the point that I never used a bow the moment I learned my first magic ability. Thirdly, healing. What kind of game doesn't sell potions? Crafting potions asides, why can't I even craft multiple potions all at once?? Its not like monster would come into the caldron room and stab me. And finally, autosaves and manual saves. This is the first offline game I've seen without a manual save which can be very frustrating when you have to walk the previous 2 maps just to get back to where you died because autosave happens in like every ?? minutes. Overall, if you're a melee lover, I won't really recommend this game as half the time, you'd get knocked down from a cliff if you try to smack a target guarding a chest there and so on. But if you're a magic lover, go ahead and get this game, you won't regret this.

I really enjoyed this for the first 15 hours or so, but the last few areas went from clever and challenging, to cheap and tedious. Quests became very redundant after a while, and the skill system started to show its limitations pretty hard as you got to the end.  Story is fun enough, but the ending is lame, and the severe lack of variety of magic weapons is amazing. I found maybe 2 magic axes (the melee weapon i focused on) the entire game, and a legendary/named axe that was severely outclassed as soon as I leveled up.  In the end, i feel kinda....meh about it.

I enjoyed this game.  + It reminded me a lot of the games of my youth like Crystal Caves and Secret Agent, which I also recently played. + Great graphics and audio. + The story was enjoyable with many good injokes about 'nerd' culture. - Some of the bosses are extremly difficult (took me a week for one of them, bloody Beholders)

This game is overall fun, witty and generally a good play. Learning the enemy weaknesses will provide a good amount of challenge, as will the numerous bosses. It has several well desgined features, such as the map, and levelling system (even if it could be a bit more forthcoming with those levelling points!) I played most of the campaign before I looked online for the ending (there's a decision bit and I wanted to see what impact it had.) I would reccomend to al future players not to. DO NOT LOOK UP THE END OF UNEPIC!Other than the occasional platfoming area, I absolutely loved this game, and am looking forward to subsequent playthroughs. I also arpologise for any spelling mistakes I may have made while writing this comment. If you are looking for a fun game to kill quite a lot of time, Unepic is certainly a good play through for you.

Since this game was advertised as a Metroidvania style game, and I have enjoyed that genre a great deal in the past I figured I would give this game a go. Sad to say that it seemingly takes the worst aspects of the genre and drops what makes games like Castlevania great.   The combat and platforming are very sluggish, leaving little room for dodging or complex maneuvers. The game does accommodate this style of slower more deliberate gameplay, but it leaves little room for interesting enemy dynamics or platforming puzzles. The mechanics never really felt natural as I played, though the difficulty never rose to the point where I had to hone my mechanics or knowledge of the game even on a higher difficulty. The boss fights are pretty simplistic since the game does not expect you to be able to move a great deal.    The RPG aspects generally just randomly help or hurt you rather than truly encourage different styles of play. If you decide to go into axes vs. maces, the only real difference will be some enemies take more damage from one. I ended up just saving up points for if a challenge presented itself and I needed to skill differently rather than develop an actual character.    The writing is quite awful, perhaps some of the worst I have seen in a game (a quick note to writers, a reference is not a joke), with the low handing fruit of nerd jokes making up a majority of the humor (think Big Bang Theory). So the writing ranges from cringe inducing references (having Admiral Ackbar say “It’s a trap”, literally), to just lazily having Zoidberg run across the screen.    The art design is not particularly inspired, with sprite design looking closer to stock images and backgrounds with very little definition or dynamism.  There were a few good aspects to the game that kept it appealing for a time. The exploration was crafted with more care than the other areas mentioned above, with a cool lighting mechanic to encourage discovery. The magic system is pretty intricate and has some good ideas tucked in there (though there was some required grinding involved).   Overall though the exploration action platformer genre is getting quite light these days, but there are better titles that are not weak in so many areas. I am really disappointed in this title considering its promise.
Just started playing this game, and I'm enjoying it. A must have game if you an RPG gamer. Good for gamers that want to try an RPG platformer.

I had been eying this game for a while now. Figured no better time to buy it than when its on sale right? Well i can tell you from just the small amount of time I played it I was so captivated that I purchased two more copies so I could play it with a couple friends. If you enjoy old school RPG's and the style of the sidescollers this game is influenced by then do not fear to click that Purchase Button. Anything else would be... UnEpic.

Very addictive 'metrodvania' game with a lot of references from Star Wars, D&D, Dune, The Golden Child, and other nerdy past times. Really enjoyed this game, hoping for a sequel. Game experience is well worth the full price and it's a steal on sale.

Great Castlevania-like game. hell better than great. This is one of my favorite video games period. I've already logged 45 hours into this game and I'll probably log in 45 more. The multiplayer co-op mode is a seperate huge game thats continuisly being developed to this day and has tons of fan made content as well.

EDIT: 31 hours in, Hard complete. I stand by my original review, this game kicks ♥♥♥. Here's a warning though, it WILL have you pulling your hair out, rage quitting and yelling profanity at the screen. These are the qualities that make it a good game though, it will not let you just sun around with a sword and slash everything till it dies. You can try, but you'll die. You actually need to think to complete some of the later stages of the game, but there is almost always more than one tactic that could be employed.  There is a certain boss that people are crying about on the forums, frankly I found him to be one of, possibly the best, boss in the game. Why? Because he is ****ing irritating as hell, has a ton of cheap tricks and you will have to reload earlier saves the first few times you face him unless you pick up on the very, very tiny hints to his abilities or read up on him. Why does this make him a good boss? Because I had to change my boxers after finally killing him, it was that damn satisfying.  This game does not cater to the new generation of whiny gamers who want to be handed everything for repeatedly bashing a single button. It is a throwback to when games were brutal and were designed to stop you completing them, not help you. Personally, this is the type of game I love.  Old review: I normally don't review, but UnEpic has earned this one fair and square. Hands down one of the best games I've played in the last year.  I've played 9 hours, almost straight(damn real life commitments), so far. Playing on Hard and completing everything I see. Despite this game's name I can assure you, it truely is epic. It costs almost nothing and from the rate I'm going, I'm looking at 25-30 hours for a full complete, including the secret challenges, at a guess.  Combat I haven't found to be repetative at all yet, there are tricks to beating certain enemies but often the layout or other enemies mean you have to adjust your tactics. You can't just run around fireballing every monster, or whacking it with a sword.  The game has a ton of character and some of the cutscenes have had me sitting here laughing so much I've had to hide in a save spot till I could calm down.  I would have been quite happy with this game if I paid £15-20 for it, to get it for about £5 is unbelievable. You can tell this game was made by someone who wanted to release a great game and actually enjoys this genre, not by a corporation trying to cash in on what people want.  All in all, this game delivers in every respect.
Simply awesome.
I thoroughly enjoyed this Metroidvania game! Buy it for the great gameplay, stay for the humor! :)

The basic gameplay of UnEpic is solid but boring RPG combat. The main character is very unlikable. The RPG system has all the basics you'd expect, but adds nothing special. The combat is dull and annoying. Enemies are too easy if you have the right skills, but if you don't it becomes a very slow game of attack, retreat, heal, repeat. There is a lot of backtracking.   I might have enjoyed this game as a vanilla RPG game, but the addition of the awkward humor and the 'nasty nerd' main character makes it an unpleasant experience.
don't be fooled, this game is epic and it knows it!

At first I really wasn't sure about it since I've got it for nearly nothing out of a humble bundle but after getting trolled by the game and died three time in a row, I started to understand what kind of funny/exploration/rogue-like/DarkSoulesque side-scroller adventure UnEpic was.After two hours, I've unlocked 2 zone,many weapons,a couple of armor pieces,potion recipes and walked around naked while slaying unforgiving enemies & environment, yes you read that right, walking around naked. I enjoy the kind of humor they've put in place,since your character is a real geek, there's lots of reference to video games,movies & popular culture. So far so good, for 13$ I think it deffinetely worth it with the single player only but there's more to it as you can play it online too, co-op or pvp, official campaign or fan made maps !
This game has a great story, and a large castle to explore akin to Castlevania SOTN.

Grab three friends and give it a go. Tons of fun in multiplayer, we found ourselves laughing to tears while we died to the horrible traps and massive '♥♥♥♥ YOU's the game throws at you. Single player is a good experience too, actually has a lot of content.  This was a surprising game, one of those hidden gems you don't expect much about then end up having tons of fun with
A great visit back to the golden age of 2d rpg's as a modern day protagonist.

This game is awesome. The multiplayer mode is awesome as well since the story is not same as in solo. However, there is (at my knowledge) no way to create a dedicated server. and that sucks, if none of your friends as a decent connection, you'll have to endure the lags.  For this reason, multiplayer mode is yet to improve. The solo story is awesome and well thought.  I recommend this game.

Good atmospheric adventure in a castle. About 20hours gameplay.

A difficult if quirky game based around the idea of a D+D player entering into a dungeon for real... while he was going to the bathroom. This game is very tongue in cheek, with a lot of humorous dialogue and tons of pop culture references. I never know what it's going to throw next at me.   Gameplay-wise, it's on the hard side. Controls are a bit sluggish but generally alright. Level gaining is on the slow side and there's a good deal of item management to be done, although I wouldn't go so far as to call it 'micro management'. You will learn to use your hot keys as you enable your bag of tricks to approach each situation. What's the right type of weapon for this? Maybe a spell? How about a potion to bypass a situation? The game gets you thinking about practical applications to your bag of tools, so to speak. Sometimes however, you just don't have anything relevant to use which can make an otherwise normal looking encounter damn near impossible.   UnEpic has bits of tutorial sprinkled throughout (admittedly, they come up at odd times) but the game doesn't hold your hand on much of anything- there's a lot you need to figure in terms of how something works. Losing hp for no clear reason? Check your inventory instead of your status display; you got leeches! Falling down a pit? No worries, you take no falling damage. But beware checking your inventory- the game doesn't pause during this! Once you get your head around the many quirks, you will find a tough game with a gigantic map, tongue-in-cheek jokes, and a challenge level that reminds me of old unforgiving games like the Pitfall series. Although frustrating at times, UnEpic is pretty damn sweet.

A fun and strangely addictive platformer RPG; the graphical style and inventory management reminded me a lot of Terraria (although UnEpic is not a randomized open-world game like that). I appreciated the ability to add notes to the in-game map, a feature so few games have.  It's humour invokes plenty of pop-culture references (and amusing guest appearances)... but be warned: the humour is sometimes surprisingly juvenile... the f-bombs, racial stereotypes and lewd sexual situations seem jarring sometimes in this environment. (There is an option to say you are under 16 years-old when you first run the game, which may actually fix this complaint if it removes the edgier stuff...)

This is one of my favourite games on Steam, and I can definitely say it's in my Top 10.  Everything about it is perfect, from the combat to the dialogue, the story to the enemies. It manages to be both serious and incredibly funny all at once, and I found myself caring about the characters a great deal before I was even halfway through the game. I didn't really expect to be so taken by the castle and the characters, but here I am a year later and I still fangirl over everything. Also, the maps are beautiful, and the music fits in perfectly with every setting! SO GOOD.   Also, I have to say that the voice acting was great-- I don't think they could have picked better people to voice everyone.  Y'all should play this game.

UnEpic is a non-linear RPG platformer. UnEpic begins with the game’s hero, an average guy called Daniel, playing an RPG fantasy board game with his friends. When Daniel heads to the bathroom, the lights go out and Daniel finds himself transported to a castle. Daniel shrugs this off as a hallucination and plays along with the cast of weird and wonderful characters he meets on his journey as fantasy. Daniel learns that his ultimate goal is progress through the castle and to slay its master – Harnakon.  UnEpic’s levels look like an 8-bit adventure game, littered with enemies, traps and rewards for the intrepid adventurer. The standard RPG components are in this game like: earning XP, upgrade abilities with points, making potions, learning spells, trading and encounter many different (funny) types of side quests.  The game tries its best to poke fun at itself, making jokes about the genre that it’s paying homage to, with nods to the classics weaved into the dialogue between Daniel and Anokra Bash.   UnEpic would be an excellent addition to any RPG fans library. UnEpic could ultimately be compared to 8-bit Marmite; if you love RPGs you’ll enjoy it – hate them and it’ll leave a bitter taste in your mouth and hunger for something different.
